questions.stem_html: Is the glass half full or half empty in this figure?

steps.content_html:
MathML rendered by MathJax: x2

Links to Physics
Astrology: Galileo’s Ship
Grasp Check
Why did the tennis ball appear to be going straight up and down at the same time that it moved along a curved path?

The idea that a description of motion depends on the reference frame of the observer has been known for hundreds of years. The 17th-century astronomer Galileo Galilei [link] was one o

Tips for Success!
In some books x or s is used instead of d to describe position. In addition, a subscript is sometimes used to describe horizontal position, dx, or vertical position, dy.Rice Link

steps.title: The Moving Man
steps.content_html:
The Moving Man

With this animation, you can produce both variations of acceleration and velocity shown in [link], plus a few more. Vary the velocity and acceleration by sliding the red and green markers along the scales. Keeping the velocity marker near zero will make the effect of acceleration more obvious. Try changing acceleration from positive to negative while the man is moving. We will come back to this animation and look at the “Charts” view when we study graphical representation of motion.
